text: A comprehensive structure for preparing for the Common Admission Test (CAT), covering all three major sections and their specific sub-topics.
This section tests mathematical proficiency, focusing on numerical ability, problem-solving, and mathematical concepts ranging from arithmetic to advanced algebra.
This section assesses the ability to interpret data from charts and graphs, as well as the ability to think logically and solve complex puzzles.
This section evaluates English language skills, focusing on reading speed, comprehension, critical thinking, and grammar usage.
A branch of mathematics dealing with symbols and the rules for manipulating those symbols, including equations and inequalities.
The study of numbers and the basic operations between them, forming the foundation for commercial mathematics and daily calculations.
The fundamental study of properties of integers, including divisibility, prime numbers, and remainders.
A branch of mathematics concerned with properties of space, shapes, sizes, and relative positions of figures.
Advanced mathematical concepts that include counting principles, probability, and sequences.
Mathematical equations where the highest power of the variable is one, representing straight lines in coordinate geometry.
Polynomial equations of the second degree, typically in the form ax^2 + bx + c = 0.
Mathematical notation representing the number of times a number is multiplied by itself, including rules of indices.
The inverse function to exponentiation, used to solve for exponents and simplify complex multiplication or division problems.
Mathematical sentences comparing two values that are not equal, using symbols like <, >, or â‰ .
Relationships where every input has a unique output, including graphs and mapping concepts.
A number or ratio expressed as a fraction of 100, crucial for data interpretation and profit calculations.
Comparative relationship between two quantities and the equality of two ratios.
Commercial math concepts dealing with cost price, selling price, margins, and discounts.
Calculations regarding the cost of borrowing money, covering both Simple and Compound Interest.
Techniques for solving problems involving combining different solutions or ingredients, often using the rule of allegation.
Problems dealing with the relationship between the amount of work done, the time taken, and the efficiency of workers.
Physics-based math problems calculating the relationship between how fast an object moves, the time it takes, and the distance covered.
Numbers that divide another number evenly without leaving a remainder.
Techniques to determine the last digit of a calculation involving large powers or products.
Methods to determine the highest power of a prime dividing a factorial and calculating the number of zeros at the end of a number.
A systematic approach to finding the remainder when a polynomial or number is divided by another.
Highest Common Factor and Lowest Common Multiple; concepts used to solve synchronization and divisibility problems.
Basic geometric concepts involving straight lines, parallel lines, transversals, and angle properties.
Properties of three-sided polygons, including area, congruence, similarity, and centers (centroid, incenter, etc.).
Study of curved geometric figures, including properties of chords, tangents, secants, and arcs.
Properties of four-sided polygons such as squares, rectangles, parallelograms, and trapezoids.
Geometry using a coordinate system to define the position of points, lines, and shapes on a plane.
Calculations of the total area of the surface and the space occupied by 3D objects like cubes, cylinders, and spheres.
Study of n-sided closed figures, including interior and exterior angles and diagonals.
Sequences of numbers where the difference or ratio between consecutive terms is constant.
Permutations and Combinations; techniques for counting arrangements and selections.
The branch of mathematics concerning numerical descriptions of how likely an event is to occur.
Questions requiring deductive reasoning to deduce relationships, arrangements, and sequences from a given set of conditions.
Analysis of data presented in various visual formats to answer numerical questions.
Diagrams that use circles to represent sets and their relationships, overlaps, and differences.
Linear and circular seating arrangement problems based on specific constraints.
Logic puzzles involving distributing items among people or groups based on variable criteria.
Reasoning based on the rules of sports, knockout structures, and round-robin formats.
Route optimization and network flow problems usually represented by nodes and edges.
General constraint-based reasoning questions that do not fit into standard categories.
Data presented in rows and columns requiring calculation and comparison of values.
Visual representation of data using rectangular bars to compare quantities.
Data trends represented by points connected by straight line segments.
Circular statistical graphic divided into slices to illustrate numerical proportion.
Data interpretation questions presented purely in text format without visual charts.
Solving complex set theory problems involving 2, 3, or 4 overlapping sets.
Calculations involving the central value of a discrete set of numbers.
Evaluation of arguments, identifying assumptions, inferences, and logical flaws.
Exercises focused on the structure, coherence, and flow of short texts.
Answering questions based on the content, tone, and implications of a long passage.
Identifying the core components of a logical argument.
Finding the unstated premise that makes an argument's conclusion valid.
Choosing statements that either support or undermine a given logical argument.
Identifying parallel logic or analogous reasoning in different scenarios.
Selecting the option that best captures the essence of a short paragraph.
Rearranging a set of jumbled sentences to form a coherent and logical paragraph.
Filling in the missing sentence of a paragraph to ensure logical flow and completion.
Identifying the sentence that does not fit the context or theme of the given paragraph.
Strategies for effective reading, including skimming, scanning, and active reading.
Techniques for narrowing down choices by identifying logically incorrect options.
Overview of question formats such as factual, inferential, and vocabulary-based questions.
Identifying the primary purpose or central theme of the author's writing.
Analyzing the author's attitude and the organizational framework of the passage.
